38670495.review:
If you enjoy roguelikes or card battle games, this is pretty much the top of both genres, in my opinion.

Created by current Hearthstone developer Peter Whelan, it was the game that got him noticed and hired by Blizzard.  I've heard the very primitive/silly art in the game was done by his pre-teen daughters.

Don't be put off by the art, this is one of the deepest, most well designed strategy games around.  Similar to other pseudo-random games like FTL, you may be put off in the beginning by "bad luck", but know there are highly talented players who can go on incredible win streaks by optimizing every single decision made in a game.

Classes have mana (blue), action points (green), HP, can get an equipment slot (rather than having to draw and play an Equipment card, you just start with it in play), and have all sorts of different talents with a cooldown based on their class.  Thieves find extra treasure, warriors can duplicate 1 card or go berserk, monks can delete unwanted cards from their deck... there are 4 starting classes and 10 more to unlock, including advanced ones like the professor (steals and keeps cards from a monster's deck) and dragons (can't use shops but can devour monsters whole, and depending on the monster type devoured gets various bonuses and different cards)

Red "attack" cards are played for "free."  Most classes start with the lowly "attack 1" but only certain classes get access to the high attack based cards like Rallying Stroke.  Blue spell cards require mana.  Some classes like the Necromancer steal mana and can start combat with a very high starting mana count, which means they may not need to put different cards that add mana to them before they can finish off opponents.   Other types of casters may want to equip a Staff that deals damage as they gain mana through cards.   Even some "non casters" get access to spells like Blur (half physical damage taken for 1 turn), I had a monk with a very small deck that included 1 Wisdom (Gain 3 mana, draw a card) and 1 Blur and by cycling and drawing could usually draw its entire deck every turn and keep that Blur up the entire fight. 

Explore a map and fight 70+ different monster types.  Get to know them, because they all have different strengths, weaknesses, and gimmicks.  Most classes have various abilities that let them explore, scout the map and see which monsters will be easy, which will be hard, and which may be impossible for your particular deck.  A wizard may want to teleport past a particularly nasty magic-immune monster.  Or, it may hatch a plan to try one of the toughest monsters first, use its long cooldown that doubles damage and lowers resistance for 1 turn, (and maybe use Flee if it gets a bad draw).  It may want to fight some medium-difficulty monsters first and time its level ups off of easier monsters to maximize the amount of healing gained.  If it scouts that the final Floor Boss is a Titan, it may want to save money for that Crumble (exile equipment or Prayer card) in a shop to deal with its nasty starting equipment.  If you don't know the last boss is a Titan, you maybe didn't save for the Crumble, and you probably get owned.

There's lots of things to unlock, and there is a system where every game gives you a score.  You can use points from your accumulating score to "buy" achievement unlocks that have been particularly stubborn.

38599368.review: Please don't be put off by the awful graphics. This game is so good Blizzard hired the designer to work on Hearthstone!

38349825.review: This is a great genre you may not have tried before. Also, it has lots of different classes and you have to learn different deckbuilding styles for each

38215890.review: This is the ancestor of Hearthstone's free expansion, Kobolds and Catacombs, which was released on December 7-8, 2017. The developper of this game is Peter Whalen, a now senior game designer at Blizzard.

38013946.review: It was fun for a while, but it's really fucking annoying having an amazing run and and amazing build, and then you just come across nothing but monsters who are super oppressive or counter your build entirely.   Some of the monsters in this game are able to shut you out way too much that it isn't fun. One example is the Hag. Filling my deck with a bunch of curse cards to that point that all I'm drawing is curses isn't fun, it just makes me feel super unlucky that the hag is blocking my path and there's no way around so that's the end of my run yay.  Game is a tilt festival.

37918544.review:
不要被这款游戏愚蠢的外表所欺骗，这可能是你玩过最好玩的卡牌+Roguelike+RPG游戏。
灵魂画师的美术设计与复杂丰富的游戏机制之间的反差，以实际行动向我证明了什么是游戏性至上。
仿佛在讽刺那些制作精良却毫无乐趣的游戏。

昨天刚用盗贼通关，利用弓箭和skewer、jab等大量action卡在一回合内不断过牌打出大量伤害，不得不感叹这游戏设计的精妙。
弃牌，升级卡牌，购买新卡牌，action/mana资源，卡组，过牌，连携……一切优秀的卡牌游戏应具备的元素它都有
一命，地牢，解锁，随机敌人，随机商店，随机事件，随机宝箱 ……一切优秀的Roguelike游戏应具备的元素它都有
职业，升级，打怪，装备，挣钱，掉宝，boss战……一切优秀的古典RPG游戏应具备的元素它都有
Dream Quest就是一款将上述元素天衣无缝的完美融合在一起的游戏，并提供了流畅爽快的游戏体验同时极具策略性。
特点鲜明的职业系统我认为是这个游戏的精髓，有依靠attack卡和装备的战士，有延迟爆发的修道士，有依靠action过牌输出的盗贼，有靠法术资源打法术牌爆发的等，还有未解锁的职业，每套职业至少有两种build，大大增加了可玩性。
卡片的获得虽然是职业相关随机的，但可以充分利用花金币选牌/弃牌机制保障一套卡组的稳定性和强度，同时伴随的卡组的成长，我们会遇到形色各异的敌人与它们极具特色的卡组和特性，需要不同的针对，让战斗充满挑战性。
[h1]评价：
+极具策略性的卡牌战斗方式
++特色鲜明的职业设计和敌人设计
+完美的融合卡牌+Roguelike+RPG
+丰富的游戏内容
+可重玩性强
--拙劣的美术设计
评分：8
评语：再强调一遍，不要被这款游戏愚蠢的外表所欺骗！[/h1]

37862097.review:
非常有趣的卡牌+Roguelike玩法，感觉狗头人的冒险模式玩法似乎没有DQ来的丰富。

希望Peter Whalen继续给炉石加入这类型的玩法。

37851619.review:
极简主义的画风下蕴含着极具特色和可玩性的roguelike卡牌游戏。游戏类似于dbg的设定，在冒险过程中获得更强力的卡，移除牌组中较弱的卡，通过不断调整卡库构造从而解决一个又一个敌人。本游戏中有将近100种敌人，每种敌人都有自己的特色，各个BOSS更是特点分明，往往要根据遇到的不同敌人选择不同的出牌策略。目前给我感觉可能还是会有很重的运气成分，然而本游戏策略度的确不低，是一款可以深入研究的游戏。虽然可能不是最好玩的roguelike游戏，但绝对是一款值得杀时间的佳作。也希望随着炉石新环境的冒险模式的推出，能让更多人知道这款出自炉石设计师Peter之手的《地城任务》

P.S 终于用武士打通了正常模式地城 我的路还有很远啊=-=

35623477.review:
'Not Recommended'... for the faint of heart.

Dream Quest is a classic like Diablo 2 or Guild Wars 1, mashing all of fantasy into a single coherent design. It's clever, charming, and tries not to take itself too seriously. Still, it is a marred experience. 

Sometimes dungeon progression will be blocked by a monster 2 levels higher than you. Sometimes you'll whiff every shot on a 20% miss chance. Sometimes you'll fight a hand of glory. Most commonly, you won't be offered removal for the 5 or so bad cards each deck is pre-loaded with.

If that's not enough to scare you, then Dream Quest is absolutely a game you should play. But as always in the dungeon: Tread Carefully!

34752611.review: Dream Quest has extremely satisfying gameplay. The interface, art, and story were clearly not prioritized, but the decision to focus on gameplay pays off handsomely with a well tuned and satisfying combat and progression system. Definitely recommended.

34665523.review:
I really really like this game, but there's a few things about it that make it where I can't recommend it. It's super addictive (almost too much so,) but the difficulty is super frustrating even on medium. It seems the more cards I've unlocked, the harder it is to build a deck with good synergy every run, and that just doesn't feel right. They should make an option to block out certain cards. Also, death feels like a slap in the face sometimes. Roguelikes are supposed to be notorious for being unfair, but there are some runs where it felt there was literally nothing I could do to stop from being killed. Even when looking for misplays and recognizing them, they hardly change anything.

Please tweek the difficulty a bit, maybe add some kind of director. I am so close to on the cusp for recommending this game.

Oh yeah, and graphics, but whatever. Gameplay is more important.

33625248.review:
如果你有幸看到这款游戏，恭喜你，捡到宝了。
窝自己是一个roguelike和DBG卡牌桌游的爱好者，也有不少游戏将两者结合在一起，但是做不到像dream quest那样天衣无缝。
本游戏是有ios版的，只要18元，以至于窝第一次想把自己的安卓机换了。。。。（处理办法是在女票的iPhone上买了一个就可以躺着玩了！）
看商店界面很多人会被画风劝退，游戏基本上是作者自己一个人完成的，所以说作者也不擅长画画辣（ps:游戏里画得比较好的怪物是作者的父母画的）。
游戏的语言要求不是很高，看不懂的时候往往用一下或者查下字典就知道了。
窝想说，dream quest的乐趣是纯粹的，除了好玩就是好玩了。
多达10余种的英雄角色可供选择（盗贼、战士、法师、牧师、死灵法师、德鲁伊、游侠、刺客、圣骑士、武士、吟游诗人、龙、教授），并且每个英雄自己有自己的专属天赋和卡牌套组。战士自带武器，盗贼会背刺，法师有冰法雷法火法毒法各种体系，德鲁伊会变身狼人等等。（ps：教授真TMD好玩啊）
游戏里的成就比较类似以撒的结合，解锁成就的同时是可以解锁新的角色，卡牌和天赋的。有些成就的解锁非常困难，导致有些卡牌或者角色你可能会觉得拿不到，但是！！！这个游戏的成就是可以买的！每局游戏结束会给你一定的成就点数，攒够了就可以买各种成就辣~
游戏中的战斗通过和怪物互相出牌，卡牌的种类分行动卡（花费行动点），spell卡（花费法力值），攻击卡，mana卡（补魔），祈祷卡，被动卡，装备卡。卡组是靠路上商店，开宝箱，删卡屋或者换牌屋来自己自由组合的，卡牌与英雄之间的技能，装备能打出各种各样的combo。
更神奇的是不同的怪物也有自己的技能和强大的卡组，女妖，巫婆，食尸鬼，斯芬克斯，美杜莎，九头蛇，凤凰，吸血鬼王，以及boss梦境领主等等。窝可以说他们的卡牌和怪物本身的天性性格如出一辙，美杜莎石化你的手牌，凤凰会浴火重生，斯芬克斯教你做人。当窝自以为组了一套OTK卡组去见梦境领主的时候，窝几乎是绝望的，玛德这玩意怎么打。。。。
遗憾的是，作者已经不再更新这个游戏了，你们有些人可能玩过作者的另一个垃圾卡牌游戏——炉石传说。作者因为做了dream quest后被暴雪挖走，参与了勇闯安戈洛卡牌包的制作，所以无暇顾及更新了。
个人觉得这游戏虽然存在很小的不平衡，但丝毫不减少游戏的乐趣。现在，选择你的英雄，完成你的套牌，去挑战梦境领主吧！

33580679.review:
A competent deck-building dungeon-crawler with hillariously bad graphics. Basically a mix of Desktop Dungeons (2013) and the board game Dominion (2008). Though you can't get murdered by a level 10 goat here. 

You fight your way through three floors. On each, you encouter monsters (exp/gold) and shops and try to optimize the punching power of your deck. Each class has prefered card types, which causes them to encounter them more often: A priest or monk will find 'prayers', a mage 'spells' and a thief 'actions'.

There is 5 card types:
-the bread and butter 'attack' and deal x damage
-the actions (that require action points) that often are something like 'do something, then draw a card"
-prayers that you play and that get triggered after 1-5 turns
-equipment that give you a permanent ability for the fight (e.g. deal 1 damage for every two attack cards you play; ignore the first 3 damage every turn; ..)
-spells.. from fireball to haste

And thats the elements this surprisingly deep deck builder gets build from.

33537285.review:
Don't judge it by its art. Actually a lot of fun, fairly deep, and challenging. Definitely a buy if you can pick it up on sale.

I would pay for a sequel with actual art.

33468289.review:
Excellent idea to combine walking around a fog of war map with RPG leveling up/items, deck building, and rogue-like. This results in a somewhat original card game- one varied enough to stand out in my bloated collection, although the fantasy theme is basic.

It goes without saying that the graphics are indeed horrible and the GUI feels like 1987- especially not having auto-turn end and clicking on the treasture box to end the match. I mean, we are talking about some very bad artwork here, my friends, and very rudimentary backgrounds, text windows, and sprites. Why not use royalty free graphics or invest in some passable images? Why release a game that doesn't even have cute pixels to fool everyone into thinking it is retro? Such a target for critics. That said, I read a comment that the developer now a job with Blizzard, so they must have been impressed with his gameplay, mechanics, and programming, so in many ways the bad graphics got their attention. Kinda like how Stevie Wonder stood out as a singer because he was blind.

Most people will pass because of the lack of graphics, and that is a shame. The upgrading, unlocking skills, and randomization make this a very fun game!

33417206.review:
We've all been there. You arrive to the "Dream Quest" store page, see the art and run away screaming.

For a long time I've seen people praising this game, it still took me ages to get it and I really regret that, it's damn fantastic.

Think of Hearthstone, but with smaller decks and quicker games. You progress through the dungeon, making decisions and getting cards that you use in combat later. Combat isn't only fun, but there's tons of possible builds and ways to play.

You keep unlocking new cards and characters at a decent pace.

I've been playing for 9 hours and I can see myself playing many more. It's really hard to put down this way, you're always itching for another try.

33402057.review: 游戏素质极高，存粹无比，在ios上玩了3年依旧乐趣不减，喜欢卡牌的玩家必入！

33362746.review: I thought I could get past the graphics, and I might have been able to, but the game is also very unpolished and there's little feedback for player actions, the UI is confusing, and it's just hard to tell what's going on. This title isn't for me I guess.

33278322.review:
有毒！！！
刚刚总算是用武士第一次通关了，说到底还是要有命才能有输出啊。（其实最后还是死在了满级小怪手上，续命以后才通的）
相对于卡牌要素，游戏的roguelike元素更突出。卡牌基本上是能拿到什么就用什么了。
看似简陋的系统实则有非常高的可玩性，就是实际通关以后才发现，总共才三关，真是让人意犹未尽啊，怎么说也得来个十多关才过瘾啊。
当然，第一次通关我就已经玩了8小时，往后还有很多花样可以尝试，所以游戏最起码应该有十多小时的游戏寿命。
这游戏给我的感觉有点像是FTL，操作上没什么难度，玩法也容易上手，但却抓住了roguelike的精髓。（好吧，我也不知道什么精髓，就是不断挂掉，然后莫名其妙地上瘾）

32726630.review:
Dream Quest (DQ) is one of two games that I recommend to anyone who is looking for a great mobile experience; the other being Lost Portal.  I happily purchased this game again, during the steam sale of course, and would do so again if I find the opportunity to buy on another platform.

I have been playing DQ for several months on my phone and, I'll admit, the visuals are lackluster as f***.  The thing is, You will stop noticing the stick figures after you get into the gameplay.   If you love card games, deck-building games, and/or rogue-likes, you owe it to yourself to give this game a try.   One of my desert-island games.

30746299.review: If i made a great game like this i would try to do marketting way better. I found this gem by luck. It's among my favorites now.

30725941.review:
[b][i]Dominion[/i] meets [i]Desktop Dungeons[/i].[/b] 

It can't be described in any simpler terms, as far as I can see. There are two components to this title, the world 'board', and the fighting card game. The card game is a deck builder nearly identical in both playstyle and strategy to the IRL card game [i]Dominion[/i]. If you haven't played that card game, I guess in effort of keeping it simple, all I can say is that it is fantastic - and it works just as well here. The world map allows you to choose how you go about fighting enemies (mainly based on their level). The 'popcorn' strategy from [i]Desktop Dungeons[/i] translates quite well. There are shops and various places to visit that add to the strategy. There are meta-game upgrades, and that is cool. You can have multiple accounts, so no need for your significant other to buy it too. Nice addition.

It is [i]definitely[/i] addicting in the sense that you want to constantly do another run because 1) you learned how to build a better deck, and 2) you now have earned more starting power via meta-game upgrades.

Sounds great? Yeah, it does and it is. [b]There is a major 'con', though - the overall polish and artwork.[/b] And don't get it twisted - I don't care two-cents about graphics (I just came from playing [i]NetHack 3.6.0[/i] an hour ago). This is about the [i]quality[/i] and care that was put into the artwork. Even if you are not a career artist, you can make things nice. This game does not do that. There is no style, and it shows in spades. The music is utterly forgettable. The controls are 'meh'. You can't use the keypad or keyboard to move as far as I have tried. The mouse is what you are stuck with (but you need the keyboard to enter an account name).

[b]To add insult to injury, this was ported from mobile and it was done poorly. There are black bars on my screen. C'mon.[/b]

But at the end of the day, I think the mechanic works really well and [i]just barely[/i] justifies a positive review.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+The mix of the two mechanics works really well (although neither is unique, and both have been done exactly the same before in other games)
+Definitely has that 'one-more-run' appeal, specifically driven by meta-game upgrades

[b]Cons:[/b]
-The artwork investment standard couldn't be lower; this is the lowest point and actually puts me on the fence for a negative review
-Generic music
-Decidedly few options for controls, but what do you expect from a mobile port
-Black bars on my screen
-Apparently the mobile version is like four bucks; once again the PC market is taxed

[b]It is fun, there is no denying that - and that's why it gets my vote BUT I do find it difficult to reward the lacklustre attempt at art and a poor mobile port.[/b]

28678067.review:
Dream Quest is the best Roguelite out there with the worst art out there.

Deckbuilding works incredibly well as a primary mechanic in a short, replayable game. Deciding whether to spend your limited gold on good new cards, removing cruddy cards from your deck, or to upgrade various stats is tough, and a lot more interesting than most of the decisions you have to make in such games. Then, seeing how the deck you've built up functions against enemies (many of which have gimmicks that can utterly cripple an unprepared deck) is as satisfying as can be. Different pools of cards being available in addition to the passive and active abilities makes each class vastly different, and gives a suprising amount of variety to the experience.

My only complaint is that I'd rather be playing this on my Android tablet (there's an iOS version), but this is more than good enough to warrant playing on PC.

28607766.review: Ignore the graphics. This is probably the best deckbuilding game on Steam.

Its in my top 5 of best games of all time, and it constantly suprised me with how brilliant, exciting, rewarding, difficult, and fucking fun it was. I recommend it to everyone, and plan on giving it out to all the people I care about that play games this christmas.

28281156.review: It's obvious from the screenshots that this game has atrocious art. What's not obvious is that the deep and engaging deckbuilding game behind the art is well worth the money,

28280392.review:
(I have 50-100ish hours on the iOS version of this game, which is identical.)

A great, unique game with nothing like it - a deckbuilder roguelike with tons of classes, monsters and cards, multiple ways to win for each class and every decision you make is important. Do I fight that monster for exp, save it for a cooldown reset or ignore it? Which card should I buy? What kind of deck am I building and what is my win condition? If you look past the developer art on the cards (which does its job, cards are easy to recognize and distinguish), you have a true gem on your hands, that will keep you coming back and back to try and make a deck better than ever before. Plus, you can play the way you like. Want to replay a seed over and over to optimize it? You can. Want what an achievement unlocks, but don't feel like doing it? Unlock it with points you earn by playing.

28278662.review: One of my favorite games in the last few years. Great on Ipad, Iphone, and PC. I am generally playing Dreamquest while I'm doing anything because it's easy to pick up and put down. There is so much depth and discovery that it's kept me coming back for thousands of runs across multiple platforms. I own this game on my PC at home, on my Ipad, and on my phone. Was worth it every time! There are so many games these days that I usually end up spending the majority of time on Triple A's, but this is one of the few indie games I've run into that have soaked up hundreds of hours of my time. Introduced it to my friends and they loved it, then I introduced it to my girlfriend and we routinely do a run together before bed.  Highly recommend to anyone that likes strategy, roguelike, or card games.

28276826.review: It may say 0.6 hours on record but it's more like 600+ hours on the non-Steam version. Don't let the graphics (straight out of an early 90s Mac shareware disc) fool you, this is one of the best games out there. Semi-roguelike deckbuilder? Sure, sounds good. It will seem simple enough at first, but start unlocking new cards and classes and the full splendor of the game will show itself soon enough. This is the second time I've bought this - gladly - and I'd buy it a third time if it came out for Android devices (though that might ruin my life, this game is super addictive). Don't forget to eat the squirrels!

28274217.review:
DISCLAIMER: I haven't played this game on Steam, but as of this writing I have apparently played it more than 1200 times on iOS.  I can't speak to the technical quality of this release, but I am very familiar with the gameplay.  I bought this game here to support the developer and to preach the virtues of Dream Quest to the benighted Steam masses.

Dream Quest is the best rogue-like* I've ever played, and my favorite single-player game of all time.  I know this might be hard to believe, given the screenshots, but lurking behind those stilted stick figures is a game of exceptional ingenuity.

To boil Dream Quest down to its most basic, you select a character class and start with a deck of ~10 cards, most of which are attack cards that simply deal damage, like Attack 1.  You wander around a level fighting monsters in a series of card battles, gaining experience and gold with which you improve your deck.  At the end of each level, there's a boss, and if you manage to defeat the third-floor boss, you face a final boss that's much, much harder than anything that came before.  Individual runs take perhaps 45 minutes at the very most, though most will end much sooner than that.

The cards fall into a few basic categories.  Attack cards mostly just deal damage (sometimes of different kinds), but occasionally have other effects, like increasing the damage of future attacks or giving you a defensive buff for a turn.  Action cards do various things, and at the start of the game you're restricted to playing one per turn (this feels like it was pulled straight out of Dominion--Swiftness, for instance, is a straight-up Village clone).  Spells are like actions, broadly speaking, but they require MP to use instead of actions.  Mana cards provide the mana to cast your spells 
(sometimes with other neat effects).  Equipment cards stay out and have passive effects once played, and later in the game you can get equipment slots so that you start with them in play.  Reaction cards trigger from your hand and have some effect--for instance, if the enemy plays an attack card and you have Riposte in your hand, it cancels the attack, deals 2 damage to the attacker, and replaces itself.  It's also possible to get curses (usually just temporarily), which, in another apparent Dominion nod, are just blank cards.

Each turn, you play/discard as many cards as you can/wish to, then draw up to your max hand size.  In the early game, you will almost always just play all your cards, but later in the game there are more in-combat choices.

What's amazing about Dream Quest is the way seemingly simple mechanics unspool into one of the most varied games I've ever played.  Enemies, which are just piles of cards and HP with perhaps a passive ability, all present different and interesting obstacles.  Zombies bite you and doom you to die five turns later--better be able to kill them fast enough.  Water elementals slowly reduce your hand size.  Sphinxes forbid you from playing the most common card type in your hand, forcing you to build awkward hands in order to do anything.  This enemy variety is even more pronounced among the bosses, who all have interesting gimmicks and require different deck-building and play priorities.  The Phoenix, for example, turns into an egg for a turn when it dies, and is only truly defeated when you smash the egg; you therefore want to set up the turn where you kill the Phoenix to deal as much damage to the egg as possible.  The Gelatinous Cube slowly eats the cards of your deck, so reliance on just one card to deal damage could doom you.  Different fights feel remarkably different, especially once you get to know the contents of enemy decks and can play around them a bit.

Player characters are even more varied.  Character classes have different starting decks, cards presented for purchase/level up, and activated abilities, so it's no surprise that they play very differently from one another.  What's almost shocking is how much variety exists within each class, and how seemingly weak cards can become essential to decks.  There are numerous cards I've written off as unplayable that have turned into deck MVPs, and even after a year and a half of play I'm finding new clever interactions.  To me, this is the chief draw of Dream Quest: decks end up playing wildly differently, and can all still succeed.

Dream Quest is a hard game, but the limited length of the runs means that death is no great loss, and the difficulty makes victory satisfying.  But Dream Quest also has a very clever system for cheating death: each run earns you points (with the effective maximum being a very rare ~2k), and when you die you can spend 500 points to restart from your last level-up.  This price doubles each time you resurrect a character, so you can mitigate BS bad luck or undo a mistake a couple times, but it rapidly becomes too expensive to respawn.

These points can also be spent to unlock things you otherwise gain via in-game achievements, which is another quietly ingenious system.  There's a lot to unlock, including 10 classes and 50 cards.  I generally have mixed feelings about unlocks--they often feel like pointless content gating--but in this case, the game is satisfying without unlocks, and it offers you a means to bypass them through general play.

I have literally never played this game with sound.  The graphics are obviously poor.  The writing in the game is without exception powerfully goofy.  If these things are important, Dream Quest is probably not for you.

So who is Dream Quest for?  I would unreservedly recommend Dream Quest to anyone who's interested in rogue-likes and/or deckbuilders and can get past the graphics; if you like Dominion or Magic drafts, there's a good chance you'll love Dream Quest.

*less rogue-like than Rogue, more rogue-like than Rogue Legacy.
